subSense.def:
the fifteenth letter of the al-
phabet, between N and P

a type of large tree
which loses its leaves in winter
subSense.example:
a for-
est of oak trees

Oaks produce thou-
sands of acorns each year

subSense.def:
wood from
this tree
subSense.example: an oak table

subSense.def:
doing
what you are told to do
subSense.example:
Our old dog is
very obedient -he always comes when
you call him

subSense.def:
someone who
is obese is so fat that it is dangerous for
their health

to do what someone
tells you to do
subSense.example:
If you can't obey orders
you shouldn't be a policeman

Every-
one must obey the law

subSense.def: a thing
subSense.example:
They thought they saw a strange object
in the sky

subSense.def: an aim
subSense.example:
Their object is to
take control of the radio station

subSense.def:
a
noun, pronoun or phrase which follows
directly from a verb or preposition
subSense.example:
In
the phrase 'the cat caught the mouse',
the word 'mouse' is the object of the
verb 'caught'

subSense.def:
to say that you
do not like something or you do not
want something to happen
subSense.example:
He object-
ed that the pay was too low

subSense.def:
con-
sidering things from a general point of
view and not from your own
subSense.example:
You must
be objective when planning the future of
your business

subSense.def: an aim
subSense.example:
Our
long-term objective is to make the com-
pany financially sound

The company
has achieved its main objectives

subSense.def:
some-
thing that you must do, e.g. for legal rea-
sons
subSense.example:
You have an obligation to attend
the meeting

subSense.def:
a shape with two
pairs of equal sides, one pair being long-
er than the other
subSense.example:
The screen is an ob-
long, approximately 30cm by 40cm

subSense.def: the act of observing
subSense.example:
By careful obser-
vation, the police found out where the
thieves had hidden the money

subSense.def:
a re-
mark
subSense.example:
He made several observations
about the government

subSense.def:
to follow or to
obey something such as a law, rule or
custom
subSense.example:
His family observes all the re-
ligious festivals strictly

The local
laws must be observed

subSense.def:
to watch
something with a lot of attention
subSense.example:
They
observed and recorded all the changes
carefully

subSense.def: to make a remark
subSense.example:
I mere-
ly observed that the bus was late as usu-
al

subSense.def:
to manage to get
something
subSense.example:
She obtained a copy of the
will

He obtained control of the busi-
ness

subSense.def:
clear; easily
seen
subSense.example:
It's obvious that we will have to
pay for the damage

It was obvious to
everyone that the shop was not making
any money

subSense.def: clearly
subSense.example:
Obviously we will need to borrow vari-
ous pieces of equipment

subSense.re:
a spe-
cial occasion a special event such as a
wedding ć The baby's first birthday
was a special occasion

subSense.def:
a happening,
a time when something happens
subSense.example:
She
claimed that she hadn't seen anything
on that particular occasion

subSense.def:
happening sometimes, but not very of-
ten
subSense.example:
He was an occasional visitor to
my parents' house

We make the occa-
sional trip to London

subSense.def: sometimes, not very often
subSense.example:
Occasion-
ally he has to work late

We occasion-
ally go to the cinema

subSense.def:
the act of taking control of a place, or
the fact of being in such a situation
subSense.example:
the
occupation of the country by enemy sol-
diers

The city had been under enemy
occupation for a week

subSense.def:
a job, posi-
tion, employment
subSense.example:
What is her occu-
pation?

His main occupation is run-
ning a small engineering works

subSense.def:
be-
ing used
subSense.example:
All the rooms in the hotel are
occupied

All the toilets are occupied,
so you'll have to wait

subSense.def: busy
subSense.example:
The
manager is occupied just at the moment

Keeping a class of 30 little children
occupied is difficult

subSense.def:
to live in or
work in
subSense.example:
They occupy the flat on the
first floor

The firm occupies offices in
the centre of town

subSense.def: to use or fill
subSense.example:
Dealing
with the office occupies most of my time

body.subSense:
3. to keep someone busy ć Could you
occupy him for five minutes while I
wrap his present? (NOTE: occupies -
occupying -occupied)

subSense.def: to happen
subSense.example:
When
did the accident occur?

body.subSense:
2. to come to
your mind ć Did it never occur to you
that she was lying? (NOTE: occurs -
occurring -occurred)

subSense.def:
a very large area
of sea surrounding the large areas of
land on the Earth
subSense.example:
Ocean currents can
be very treacherous

subSense.def:
used with num-
bers to show the time
subSense.example:
Get up -it's 7
o'clock

We never open the shop be-
fore 10 o'clock

By 2 o'clock in the
morning everyone was asleep
subSense.note:
NOTE:
O'clock is only used for the exact
hour, not for times which include min-
utes. It can also be omitted:

subSense.def:
the tenth
month of the year, between September
and November
subSense.example: October 18

Do you
ever go on holiday in October?

Today
is October 18th

Last October we
moved to London

subSense.def:
a sea animal
with eight long arms called 'tentacles'

unusual and not
normal
subSense.example:
It's odd that she can never re-
member how to get to their house

He
doesn't like chocolate -Really, how
odd!

subSense.re:
odd numbers numbers such
as 17 or 33 which cannot be divided by
two ć The buildings with odd numbers
are on the opposite side of the street

subSense.def:
almost, not exact or ac-
curate
subSense.example:
She had 200 odd records in
cardboard boxes

subSense.def:
one forming part of
a pair

done only rarely or occasional-
ly
subSense.example:
I've only been to the odd concert in
the last few years

On the odd occa-
sions I've met him, he's seemed very
nice

subSense.def:
a smell, especially
an unpleasant smell
subSense.example:
the odour of rot-
ten eggs
subSense.note:
NOTE: The US spelling is
odor

subSense.def:
used for show-
ing a connection
subSense.example:
She's the sister of the
girl who you met at the party

Where's
the top of the jam jar?

What are the
names of Henry VIII's wives?

subSense.def:
used
for showing a part or a quantity
subSense.example:
a litre
of orange juice

How much of the cloth
do you need?

Today is the sixth of
March

There are four boys and two
girls -six of them altogether

Half of
the staff are on holiday

subSense.def:
used for giv-
ing a specific age, amount, etc
subSense.example:
The
school takes children of ten and over
He earns a salary of over £30,000

subSense.def: showing position, material, cause
subSense.example:
He
lives in the north of the town

The
jumper is made of cotton

She died of
cancer
subSense.note:
NOTE: Of is often used after
verbs or adjectives: to think of, to be
fond of, to be tired of, to smell of, to be
afraid of, etc

subSense.def:
used to
say 'yes' or 'no' more strongly
subSense.example:
Are
you coming with us? -Of course I am!

Do you want to lose all your money?
-Of course not!

subSense.def:
used for stating
something that is not surprising
subSense.example:
He is
rich, so of course he lives in a big house

subSense.def:
showing
movement or position away from a
place
subSense.example: We're off to the shops

The of-
fice is just off the main road

They
spent their holiday on an island off the
coast of Wales

The children got off
the bus

Take your boots off before you
come into the house

subSense.def: away from work
subSense.example: She took the week off

It's my day off
today
Half the staff are off with flu

subSense.def: not switched on
subSense.example: Is the TV off

subSense.def:
not con-
tinuously, with breaks in between

the state of be-
ing offended
subSense.example:
He took offence when I
said he looked bigger than before

subSense.def:
a
crime, an act which is against the law
subSense.example:
He was charged with committing an of-
fence

Since it was his first offence, he
was let off with a fine

subSense.def:
to be or to go
against public opinion, someone's feel-
ings
subSense.example:
He offended the whole village by
the article he wrote in the paper

That
wallpaper offends my sense of taste

subSense.def: to commit a crime
subSense.example:
He was released
from prison and immediately offended
again

subSense.def:
US spelling of of-
fence

un-
pleasant
subSense.example: What an offensive smell!

subSense.def: not polite; rude
subSense.example:
The waiter was quite
offensive

subSense.def:
a suggestion to some-
one that you will give them something
or do something for them
subSense.example:
He turned
down her offer to drive him to the sta-
tion

She accepted his offer of a job in
Paris

subSense.def:
to suggest doing some-
thing for someone or giving someone
something
subSense.example:
She offered to drive him to
the station

subSense.def:
a room or building
where you do work such as writing, tel-
ephoning and working at a computer
subSense.example:
I'll be working late at the office this
evening

We bought some new office
furniture

Dad has his office at the top
of the house

subSense.def:
a person who holds
an official position
subSense.example:
The customs offic-
er asked me to open my suitcase

subSense.def:
relating to
an organisation, especially one which is
part of a government or some other au-
thority
subSense.example:
He left official papers in his
car

We had an official order from the
local authority

He represents an offi-
cial body

subSense.def:
done or approved by some-
one in authority
subSense.example:
She received an offi-
cial letter of explanation

The strike
was made official by the union head-
quarters

subSense.def:
a person holding a rec-
ognised position
subSense.example:
They were met by an
official from the embassy

I'll ask an
official of the social services depart-
ment to help you

subSense.def:
in an offi-
cial way
subSense.example:
He has been officially named
as a member of the British team

She
has been officially named as our repre-
sentative at the meeting

subSense.def:
according to
what is said in public
subSense.example:
Officially, you
are not supposed to go in through this
door, but everyone does

Officially he
knows nothing about the problem, but
unofficially he has given us a lot of ad-
vice about it

subSense.def:
on many occa-
sions
subSense.example:
I often have to go to town on
business
Do you eat beef often?
How often is there a bus to Richmond?

subSense.def:
a liquid taken from plants
and animals, which flows smoothly and
is used in cooking
subSense.example:
Cook the vegeta-
bles in hot oil

subSense.def:
a thick mineral liquid
found mainly underground and used as a
fuel or to make something move
smoothly
subSense.example:
The door squeaks -it needs
some oil

Some of the beaches are
covered with oil

The company is
drilling for oil in the desert

subSense.def:
used for
answering 'yes' to a question
subSense.example:
Would
you like a coffee? -OK!

subSense.def:
used for
starting to talk about something after a
pause
subSense.example: 'It's ten o'clock' -'OK, let's
